White Men Are Feeling Left Out Of DEI. Why Should We Care and What Should We Do?

By Teresa Hopke

By Teresa Hopke ,

Contributor.

There are white men who feel like, "You're talking about me without including me in the ... More conversation." - Steven Humerickhouse, Executive Director, Forum on Workplace Inclusion

Back in the days of middle school gym class, getting picked for kickball may have felt as intense as any major-league draft. There would be excitement for some, but for others this situation brought on prepubescent catastrophizing and "what ifs" around possibly being among the last remaining players to get chosen.

What was so dreadful about it were the anxious thoughts of being overlooked and excluded. But of course, that would go unspoken as the captains continued to make their selections.

But here is a thought: What if the players were given the opportunity to pick which team to play on, rather than the captains picking which individuals they wanted on their team? Well, this may not have necessarily changed the way the game gets played, but it could have empowered each individual player in a way that impacted the way they showed up in the game - because the fear of being excluded was lifted off of them at the start.

Now fast forward to the current world of work where Diversity, Equity and Inclusion, when it is rightfully embedded into an organization's culture, are changing the game for the good of all. And although the mission is to ensure that employees of all genders, races and ethnicities, abilities and disabilities, religions, cultures, ages, and sexual orientations are included, have their voices heard, and receive opportunities for advancement...there is a group that has been feeling excluded from these efforts - white men.

White men hold most leadership positions and decision-making power in US society (and globally). So, at first glance, it may seem surprising to learn that they are feeling excluded from anything. But according to the White Men's Leadership Study, a study of white men and DEI, nearly 70% report feeling "forgotten" by diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts. Feeling uncertain about whether DEI includes them is the main reason they say they either disengage or are not as committed to it as others in their organization.

Is DEI really disregarding white men? And is this something that leaders should be tending to? In an effort to bring awareness, insight, and empathy to this seemingly taboo topic, I've invited Renu Sachdeva, Head of DEI, North America, Talking Talent, Inc, and Steven Humerickhouse , Executive Director of The Forum on Workplace Inclusion, both of whom are DEI champions, to help explore why white men may be feeling left out of DEI and what might be done about it.

Teresa Hopke: I think a great starting point is to acknowledge that everyone wants to feel a sense of belonging, to feel included. No one wants to feel disadvantaged, as if something is being taken away from them. But some of the stories I am hearing from white men in regard to DEI are things like:

Steven Humerickhouse: People who come with that kind of mindset automatically assume that they're not a part of the conversation and don't even want to be a part of the conversation. Because they think it limits them. And I think there is also a little bit of defensiveness around, "What can I say or do and what can I not say or do?''

Even just down to terminology, it feels like a landmine. Every step you take could be some place where it could explode on you. So, when people are looking for them (white men) to participate, they're already feeling a bit on the defense before they even show up. Because they don't want to feel accused or threatened or like a target.

Renu Sachdeva: I have also heard in the work that I've done that some white men don't like to attend DEI trainings because they feel like they're implicitly or explicitly being blamed for the current state of affairs, or that they're being shamed for having the privileges they have. Then there is the concept of feeling disadvantaged, which is the thought of, "Well if you are giving more opportunities to women, people of color etc, then that means you're giving fewer opportunities to me." This is zero-sum bias thinking, which can happen consciously or unconsciously. And there are some white men who would say, "We just want it to be equal. It's not fair that women and minorities are being given more preference over us. We just want it to be fair."

Hopke : Steven, what was it like for you when you got involved in DEI?

Humerickhouse: When I got involved in DEI work over 20 years ago, it wasn't a job I wanted. It was a job I got. I mean, look at me, I'm a white guy, right. My daughter was adopted from Honduras, so I had some lived experience with this diversity thing, but it wasn't something that I myself thought I needed to live because I was a white guy, and I had all that privilege. But I saw possibilities at The Forum . There were things in my skill sets that I knew could help move this thing along, and everyone was really passionate about what they were doing. So, I learned all the DEI stuff on the way, literally listening to our community members and reading proposals and whatever else I could get my hands on.

White people don't think they have race and are different. I have the power and privilege, so everybody else is different from me. But when I went to China a couple of years ago, I was the difference. I got some deference because I was an older man, so age has had some privileges in China. But otherwise, I didn't speak the language. I couldn't access the transportation system. I definitely stood out in that space in Shanghai. This idea of race, it's all relative and so white people don't see themselves in that. Other people live it every day. My daughter is Latina. She lives that every day, and my grandchildren who are mixed race of Black and Latino live that every day. So, we are really all in this, but the white folks don't always know that they are. That was, I suppose, the growth moment for me in the beginning. That was the learning experience for me...that I am a part of this.

Hopke: What do you think needs to happen to get white men to a space where they are open and willing to embrace the ideas of a more inclusive culture - especially when there are walls built up from what they see as an attack on who they are?

Humerickhouse: White men are feeling the pressure. It's all about fear and so we have to think about it in that way. We have to ask ourselves if in our DEI spaces, are we really open to hearing those missing voices? I suppose there are white men who feel like, "You're talking about me without including me in the conversation."

We also have to think of the empathy piece and meeting people where they are. There can be all kinds of reasons why they are where they are. They can be racist. They can be ignorant. They can be owning their privilege or not ever wanting to admit that they have it. But that's where they are. I think it's about just allowing people to be who they are, and then helping them understand where their shortcomings may be.

Hopke: Yes. Coaching, conversation and heart-based experiences that create levels of empathy and compassion are the key to making progress. We can't push, pull, force or shame white men into the DEI conversation. We have to invite them in. Help them see what's in it for them. Help them see that they aren't under attack. And most importantly, help them understand what to DO because many of them are paralyzed by the fear of doing the wrong thing.

Humerickhouse: I come from a very religious Republican family. My background is rural and conservative. Would people like me (but not me exactly) actually even feel comfortable in our "liberal" DEI spaces? The interesting thing is that in speeches when I talk about this feeling of loss that I mentioned earlier, I get a whole lot of texts back saying "Thank you." Because although those folks were in the room (not as many as we'd like, but they are there), they felt silenced until I called them out and said, "You're a part of this conversation."

DEI work is a lifelong learning thing. There is no end point for the work itself and there's certainly no endpoint for the individual journey until, of course, the journey is over.

So, how DO you open yourself up, white man, to be able to be more aware? Let's take the Crown act for example. Well, say I don't understand what that means. I don't have hair like that. My hair has always been very straight. It just has always been. So, I don't know what it means for hair to be an issue. It's just something that I've never had to deal with so it's not part of my experience. I don't even have a concept of that. But that fact does not invalidate someone else's lived experience - just because I don't have that experience.

Sachdeva: And from an organizational standpoint, when organizations do DEI right, all the studies, all the business cases show that if you actually have a diverse workforce, if you have an inclusive culture, if you have equitable systems and processes, then your company will likely perform better than your competitors who may not be investing in DEI. So that's another piece to help people understand - yes, in the short term, there may be fewer opportunities for a group that was used to having access to more. But if we can grow the business and the business can be successful, in large part through our investment in DEI, then eventually there should be more opportunities for everyone. The "pie" gets bigger.

Hopke: Agree. And it's not that white men are saying that they don't care about DEI or want the pie to get bigger. Most of them say that they do. According to one study, 42% of white cis-gendered men believe that DEI is "extremely important." So, how white men show up for DEI may look different, but their support is still there and still needed. Inclusive leaders will do the work to go after that support, because they know that DEI is an "all hands on deck" commitment.

White men can be powerful allies, advocates, mentors, and sponsors for diverse talent. Then there's the impact that can come from when they are acknowledging and lending their privilege. But if they don't feel welcome to participate in the first place, then none of this will happen - at least not meaningfully or consistently.

Humerickhouse: And we have to bring along those folks who would push back on this idea, helping them realize that people like me must be included. In fact, because we (white men) do have power and privilege, we can't advance this (DEI) unless we use that power and privilege to advance others and give power and privilege to others.

Ultimately, if you feel like you belong, the likelihood is that someone has made you feel like you do. We all need to feel that sense of belonging and whether that's based on your race, gender, orientation, or different ability from other people in the organization, we all want to be in a place where we feel "at home." That's no less true for a white man.

Hopke: Inclusive leaders will need to remember that even if someone isn't initially supportive of DEI, they can still be reached and enlightened on the importance of the issue. We just need to lift the fear of exclusion for them. We need to assure them that the childhood playground teams traumas aren't at play today and rid them of zero sum thinking. As you build your DEI strategy, be mindful not to unintentionally exclude white men. And at the same time, white men also need not exclude themselves, because they are a critical part of the mission to build a more fair and inclusive world. And that right there is why we should care!

The Liberation Of Learning About Race: A White Man's Journey Toward Anti-Racism

By Nell Derick Debevoise

By Nell Derick Debevoise ,

Senior Contributor.

Dr. Garrett Weatherhead is a licensed psychologist in private practice in the suburbs close to Grand Rapids, Michigan. He is a husband and father of two girls, ages six and three. We had this conversation about the portion of his anti-racism journey that has emerged from Dr. Weatherhead's podcast interview with Klay S. Williams, our mutual friend and colleague.

Nell Derick Debevoise: I strongly encourage readers to listen to your conversation with Klay S. Williams, but for now, would you summarize the podcast that led us here?

Dr. Garrett Weatherhead: Klay followed up to a Facebook post I made that said something like, "I am ready to live into a more consistently anti-racist space for my personal life." He called and invited me to discuss the post on his podcast It was very scary, and I didn't know what I was in for, but I said yes. On the podcast, he wonderfully took me through my journey from not thinking racism is a big deal to where I'm at now, where I see becoming anti-racist as a primary part of who I am and what I'm here to do.

The podcast centers on my doctoral studies. I went to a program with a focus on multiculturalism, and really, race and racism. How does race and racism affect relationships, mental health, and every aspect of psychology. Within the program, I was forced to think and talk about race and racism nearly every day for five years. That experience shifted how I saw the world in a very deep way. It shifted how I think about myself and my relationships.

Derick Debevoise: What has your anti-racism journey looked like since you and Klay recorded the podcast six months ago?

Weatherhead: Before the podcast, I was doing therapy and enjoying it, having seen that work as aligned with my purpose for a long time. One of Klay's questions was, "How does your anti-racism journey intersect with your sense of purpose?" I had not thought about that connection previously, but now I've been thinking about it near daily. I've come to understand that my purpose is to enter this anti-racist space consistently in personal and professional ways. That's the shift that occurred after the podcast.

Listen to Weatherhead and Williams discuss the messiness and liberation of the anti-racism journey.

Derick Debevoise: Does your anti-racism play out in what you do or how you do things?

Weatherhead: Both. It has played out in what I do, because I have spent a lot more time thinking and considering what work I can do in this anti-racism space. It's been a conversation with my wife about making more time in my schedule not for doing therapy but for thinking about anti-racism. In terms of how I do things, I think I'm more open than I was. I think previously, if you knew me, you might know about my anti-racism journey. My hope is that now, if you know me, you definitely know about my commitment to anti-racism. The shift in how I do things is being much more upfront about who I am in this space.

Derick Debevoise: What insights have come from your anti-racism journey?

Weatherhead: Wrestling with my purpose and anti-racism prompted a conversation with myself about why anti-racism has become so important to me. I have realized that because of my education and the gift of understanding a little bit more about racism, I am more connected to myself. I didn't realize that racism was a disconnecting factor from my true self, but now I see that it was.

Another insight from learning about racism is how much disconnection is caused between white people and People of Color. As I've come to understand racism better, it opens the door for more genuine relationships across race. So, learning about racism offered a more genuine relationship with myself, as well as with others across race.

Derick Debevoise: Are there moments you've experienced that you can share to make that tangible for folks who haven't gotten there in their own journeys to anti-racism?

Weatherhead: One is a friendship with a Native American woman from my doctoral program. I talk a little bit about this in the podcast: my relationship with her got to a depth that it could not have had I not known about racism. White people hurt People of Color all the time, mostly unintentionally, because of our lack of understanding about what our whiteness has done and continues to do. Being able to talk through that with Deidre got our relationship to a depth that it couldn't have gone otherwise.

Derick Debevoise: You shared that talking about your anti-racism journey with other white people has been tiring, difficult, even painful at times. But your experience matches the research and anecdotal evidence that healthy relationships across race is good for team performance. Have you seen that benefit, and does it make the effort of becoming anti-racist worthwhile?

Weatherhead: 100%. If learning about race and racism can help me to better know my true self, and have more intimate relationships with people across race, wouldn't that be wonderful for other white people to know too? Sometimes, when I talk about racism with other white people, it's terrible. It's hard, it's uncomfortable. It can even be harmful to them or our relationship sometimes.

But if we can switch the lens to an invitation, to explain that there's a reason to do this work. If you can learn more about racism, you can have a more genuine life with yourself and more genuine relationships across race. That invitation is a shift from, "Hey, let's engage uncomfortably about racism," to, "Hey, let's see if we can get to more depth in our relationships with ourselves and each other."

Derick Debevoise: It feels like liberation for us as white folks, from not needing to have these conversations about race, because we're white and that's the default or 'norm'. But what you've experienced is that to do this anti-racism work opens up the richness, complexity and pain and beauty of what race is, for all of us as humans, not just non-white folks.

Weatherhead: Absolutely. Racism is not going to change unless white people understand why it's meaningful for them to understand it. If we can shed the internalized racial superiority, we can live a more open, genuine life.

Derick Debevoise: What has been messiest along the way?

Weatherhead: When you start to understand the effect of racism, change has to happen. You have to change how you're living. For example, I was invited to a conference by a close friend. The speaker was very racist in ways that I probably would not have picked up on earlier in my anti-racism journey, but because I now did, I wanted to leave immediately. My decision to leave changed that relationship.

Another example is that as a result of my work, I wanted to parent differently. I wanted to teach my daughter, who was an infant at the time, about racism and other isms. My wife wasn't there yet. That's the complicated part of this conversation: you can do your own internal work, but when you start to move through your life, something's got to give, and not everyone is on the same page.

Derick Debevoise: Have you found that doing your work has started to impact the people around you?

Weatherhead: Yes, absolutely. Through many conversations about race and racism and how they influence our work or family, I see shifts in the people around me. I wouldn't dare take like credit for it, but that feels like a bit of a ripple. Because we got to have these conversations, their thinking and our relationships evolve. That's potent.

Derick Debevoise: As Americans, capitalists in our current system, we have a strong bias to action. But you shared that a lot of your anti-racism work right now is really just holding space and time to think. How does that feel?

Weatherhead: The thinking is moving somewhere potent. And so that feels good and feels valuable. When I first started to become aware during the doctoral program, I engaged in frenetic doing . Some benefit could have come out of it, but it was so frenetic and scattered that it felt like a drop in the bucket versus me using the strengths that I have to do anti-racism in a way that utilizes my strengths. That feels like a shift

Derick Debevoise: Well, that's the alignment of the purpose that Klay's got you thinking about. We call it Purposeful Growth: to contribute to solving the problems we care about in the ways that make best use of our unique selves.

Weatherhead: Yes. I was floundering until I got that connection. Before, I felt, "I have to be doing this, this and this," and I would run myself into the ground. I actually burnt myself out and even harmed myself and others by doing fanatically, instead of moving with my own current.

Derick Debevoise: What advice or encouragement do you have for people on their own anti-racism journey or maybe just beginning?

Weatherhead: There's a couple things that I think about. The first one is a stance of curiosity and willingness to make mistakes. If you enter conversations about race and racism with curiosity and a willingness to fail, and lean into that discomfort, then you have a chance to get further.

The second part, which has come from my doctoral program and more recent thinking with Klay, is that there are formal and informal chances to learn about racism. The formal chances were things like our professors, the really amazing anti-racism groups teaching this, books about anti-racism. And then the informal ways, are the one-on-one interactions hearing about people's personal experiences with racism and how they have affected their trajectories. Or when a Black colleague said, "I'm getting nervous about going to this conference," and then explained he didn't know if that region was safe for him as a Black man. I had never had that conversation before - those informal interactions with people who have different lived experiences than me, that has been life-changing. So we must seek out formal and informal opportunities to learn about race and racism.

Derick Debevoise: Do you regret choosing the PhD program you ended up in?

Weatherhead: Definitely not. I am more whole now. I don't think that I would be as whole as I feel now if I hadn't gone through the program. But I wouldn't have known it! I would have lived life, not really thinking about racism at all and, and not knowing that there is a different level of life available.

Derick Debevoise: Wow. Well there's a carrot for all of us contemplating the challenging prospect of beginning or deepening our anti-racism journeys... Anyone want to reach a deeper level of life experience that you may not even know today is possible? Thank you so much, Garrett, for doing your work, and for sharing it so generously.

Weatherhead: Thanks for the space. It's so nice to talk to you, the way you put things together is so wonderful. Thank you for that.

This Therapist's Message To White Men: Become An Agent Of Change Or A Victim Of Progress

By Dana Brownlee

By Dana Brownlee ,

Former Contributor.

Former licensed private-practice psychotherapist Andrew Horning, MSW now serves as a coach and ... More teacher at the Hoffman Institute.

As a couples therapist, Andrew Horning had become accustomed to a predictable yet problematic pattern-eager wife schedules appointment and arrives ready to share and engage while husband proceeds with extreme caution, even skepticism, defensiveness and at times stubborn resistance. Predictably, the husband's struggle to be vulnerable and open would invariably hinder both connection and progress within the relationship. Fast forward several years...Horning participated in a two-day DEI (diversity, equity and inclusion) workshop with a racially mixed audience. As the workshop progressed, the facilitator labored to coax more openness from the White participants-they were visibly resistant. For Horning this resistance reminded him of the proverbial husband dragged to counseling scenario he'd witnessed so many times before. To help attendees understand the privilege that seemed invisible if not fictitious to many of the White participants, the facilitator explained, "You know you have privilege when equity feels like discrimination." For Horning that moment was an epiphany. "I thought 'That's it! We have to be willing to handle the discomfort of this work internally if we are to move forward with a deeper understanding of the experience of Black and Brown people in this country.'" He noted a clear parallel between the individual White male resistance that hindered emotional intimacy and marital success and the collective visceral White male resistance and defensiveness in the workshop inhibiting productive exploration of the realities of racial inequities.

His conclusion-just like men need to grapple with themselves to show up better in their relationships, White men in particular need to grapple with their identity, their privilege and even their racist patterns to show up better in the world and become change agents for racial equity.

While it can be tempting to view racism and race-based discrimination as a Black/Brown problem, many would argue that it's really an ongoing toxicity that White people must address , particularly White men, if it's to be eradicated long term. Psychotherapist Andrew Horning has embarked on a mission to urge White men to do just that. In his new book Grappling: White Men's Journey from Fragile to Agile , Horning urges White men to grapple with the reality of their identity. "If you're a white man in America, you have a decision to make: become an agent of change or a victim of progress," says Horning. "White men have found themselves entrenched in a privileged status quo for centuries. Old patterns and learned behavior have contributed to their success, but things are changing; our world is evolving. We're tackling racism and sexism head-on, and White masculinity, as we know it, is in the midst of a revolution."

Andrew Horning's book encourages White men to grapple with their identify and privilege for inreased ... More inner peace and a stronger emotional capacity.

Horning views the process of grappling-engaging in a close struggle without weapons-as the work that White men must do to build the racial stamina required to actively lean into this moment of racial reckoning. In practice grappling requires purposely exposing oneself to discomfort in order to emerge stronger and better with a simultaneous sense of power and humility. "As White men we have to stop putting our finger in the dike that is preventing change and instead be agile in navigating it." insists Horning. "We can't just say, 'If a Black person brings it up, I'll deal with it.' Our defensiveness and avoidance is more problematic than we realize."

Recognizing that a barrier for many White men is a sense of shame, guilt or feelings of being a bad person, Horning insists that innate goodness and racist patterns are not in fact the same thing. (Similarly, Robin DiAngelo famously refers to this concept as the "good/bad binary" in her New York Times bestseller White Fragility: Why It's So Hard for White People to Talk About Racism) . "We have to realize 'I can be a good person and have racist patterns,'" explains Horning. "Patterns we learned are not us; it's learned behavior that can be unlearned." He implores White men in particular to acknowledge those patterns as a function of their upbringing and environment. "It's the water we swim in," he insists. Furthermore, he highlights the significant long-term benefits awaiting those who are brave enough to wade into this admittedly uncomfortable territory. "The feeling of discomfort or possibly shame is only a temporary state, and if we can sustain ourselves through it, we can come out the other side confident and free," he explains. "We must build up our own capacity to navigate the uncomfortable emotions that race and gender bring up among White men. We must build the muscle that has been atrophied as a result of our privilege."

That work doesn't just yield long term benefits for the individual, but it can also change how they show up in the workplace among peers and colleagues. When they meet a new person of color at a race related event, they're less likely to awkwardly rattle off their "racial resume" and more likely to actually engage with the individual. When uncomfortable discussions ensue in the workplace, they're less likely to focus their energies on defending their character and more likely to think critically about how to create more equity. Even when they might be accused of an offensive or racist comment or action, they're more likely to lean into the discussion and get curious instead of reflexively responding with defensiveness...or anger.

In his new book Horning also urges White men to step up in a new, more forceful way to become agents of change for racial reconciliation and equity. "We have to stop defending and distracting from the original sin in our country of slavery," he insists. "As White people we have to be willing to deal with the truth and be an ally and amplify the voices of Black and Brown people." Horning also challenges the concept of American meritocracy and instead considers it more of a "mirror-tocracy" as White men have continually benefited by seeing their own archetype continually reinforced and celebrated. Possibly most importantly, this grappling can yield significant tangible advances in racial equity outcomes. He insists, "When White men who hold the levers of power start grappling, larger systemic change can happen."

For those who question or criticize his focus on White men specifically, he first acknowledges that White men are undeniably at the top of the proverbial food chain in America, a phenomenon that Pulitzer Prize winning author Isabel Wilkerson explores in her New York Times bestseller Caste: The Origins of Our Discontents . "This potent, problematic and paradoxical combination of whiteness and maleness has given us so much and yet left us with so little," admits Horning. "We have so many advantages that largely go unacknowledged and unseen by us, and those privileges have left us with fewer skills at dealing with the changing world around us." He asks White men to grapple with the idea that they're not entitled to psychological comfort and to consider the fact that insistence on comfort may be what's preventing many of them from progressing from fragile to agile. For this reason, he refers to the "gift of the grapple" insisting that this conscious exposure to what's uncomfortable ultimately yields more inner peace and a stronger emotional capacity.

While it may be tempting to paint a myopic view of white supremacy as men in hoods burning crosses in yards, the truth is that the general ideology of White male supremacy is much more subtle, nuanced and ubiquitous. As a White male psychotherapist, Horning has grappled with that himself and asks other White men to join him in grappling with their White male identity. He reflects, "As White men, we have been lauded for changing the world, then we were told to change yourself first and then change the world. This new era is asking us to first allow the world to change us. We don't know what we thought we did, and that is a hard place to be when you aren't used to it."

Stay tuned for the follow up article based on Horning's work "If You're Ever Called Out As 'Racist' At Work, Remember These Four Simple Steps."

White Men Are Feeling Left Out Of Diversity, Equity, & Inclusion. Why Should We Care and What Should We Do? - Part 2

By Teresa Hopke

By Teresa Hopke ,

Contributor.

If you've got a real diversity of people and are trying hard to connect and collaborate and be real, ... More then you're going to make some mistakes, but you're not going to let them slide.

For those who love a good board game, a few rousing rounds of Taboo can be an entertaining way to unwind (or in my case, get the competitive juices flowing). But what if the game took on a more serious tone? What if instead of trying to guess celebrities or TV show titles, a player pulled a card where their team had to guess why white men feel excluded from DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) initiatives? How do you think you'd do with that one?

Chances are, most would probably take one look at that particular card and put it at the bottom of the deck until maybe it came back up again. That's because, unfortunately, confronting the idea of white men feeling excluded from DEI is a real taboo topic.

This issue goes beyond the idea of white men feeling uncomfortable around conversations on diversity and inclusion. The deeper conversation that we need to have is that some white men believe that they can never truly be authentic in expressing how they feel about how inclusion has led to their exclusion. It has also led many of them to resentment and resistance towards embracing DEI efforts altogether.

The reality is that DEI initiatives are often designed with everyone but white men in mind. This is due to the fact that marginalized groups are the ones who have been historically excluded and underrepresented. It's the diverse talent in organizations that are also more likely to experience bias, discrimination, and microaggressions.

Meanwhile, white men have had the advantage, and just as we pointed out in part 1 of this series, they hold most leadership positions and decision-making power in US society (and globally). So many people simply don't recognize that white men can possibly feel excluded from DEI. It can be easy to assume that white men don't face any barriers and do not experience feeling left out.

However, despite their privileged status and access to positions of power, some white men are feeling like their voices are ignored, or that their concerns are dismissed as irrelevant, unimportant or offensive. Additionally, they may be less likely to see themselves as essential (as everyone is by the way) to DEI efforts, and therefore feel hesitant or even resistant when it comes to supporting these initiatives.

People resist what they don't feel connected to or see a need for. So, it's imperative that inclusive leaders cultivate safe, supportive environments that inspire even the reluctant to embrace DEI for the benefit of all.

To help inclusive leaders better understand why white men feel left out of DEI and how to engage the resisters I'm joined by Michael Baran , social scientist and Senior Partner & Digital Solutions Lead at InQuest Consulting and co-author (with Dr. Tiffany Jana ) of Subtle Acts of Exclusion , for part two of this critical conversation.

Teresa Hopke: Michael, I know that DEI issues matter tremendously to you in the work that you do. I am curious about how you came to be involved in this work.

Michael Baran: I chose this career path, and I would call it a path because I didn't know exactly where it would end, really out of a fascination with people and a passion to create equity and inclusion cultures and systems where people could be treated equally. Through getting to know a diversity of people and hearing their stories and traveling and seeing the world, I just got really fascinated by these issues and wanting to understand them.

We all have unconscious bias that's the way just the way it is, but that wouldn't be enough for me. I had all these questions, like wait a minute....why, DO we have these biases in our heads that we don't even know are there and we wouldn't want to be there?? How does that happen? And what do you mean cultures can make some people feel really valued and welcomed and respected and other people, not so much?"

The ways in which that happens are really subtle and hard to see. So, I went and got my doctorate in cultural anthropology and cognitive psychology to really investigate those questions. I spent eight years diving into that trying to understand how it happens from birth to adulthood, and with the idea being when we really understand what's going on we can better figure out what to do about it.

I needed to really figure it out myself before figuring out what to do about it. And figuring out what to do about it led me to deeper work with organizations. I first did some teaching. I taught at Harvard for a while and just started a consultancy on the side and it just snowballed to the point where I knew I had to do it full time and that it was really my calling.

One of my special skills in this space is, I think I can really explain it to people in a way they understand. Like to a white man who doesn't have the experience with it and doesn't have that deep understanding, I can explain it in a way that makes sense. Because they don't get the foundational part of it, and so we really need to help them along on the journey, while also recognizing that we're not all starting from the same place.

Hopke: As I was reading your book and your work concerning human behaviors, particularly bias, it hit me that you've researched and investigated these issues similar to how Brene' Brown has studied vulnerability and shame. Especially with how particular you are with how you provide understanding and language to the experience of exclusion.

Baran: Absolutely. I mean that's the basis of some of the work in Subtle Acts of Exclusion . Understanding those subtle interactions that are really going on with communication. Conveying all of these unintended messages to people that are real. They're under the surface.

One of the cool things about cultural anthropology is you train yourself to go and live in a place where the culture is entirely unfamiliar to you. I lived for two years in northeast Brazil.

And so, the idea is that you can't take anything for granted, none of your assumptions about people work. All you can do is ask questions. And really listen to people's answers and observe. Soon, you get to the point where that starts to feel really comfortable and normal and natural to you. Then you come home and that's where the real culture shock is. You start to see things in your own culture from a more objective and clear perspective.

Hopke: I'd say that DEI is bringing about some culture shock. And some of that culture shock isn't sitting well with the majority. How can inclusive leaders reach those in the majority who are resistant to DEI, but do it in a way that still keeps the focus on its purpose - creating fair and equitable workplace cultures, especially for marginalized groups that have historically been excluded?

Baran: I think some practical things that can happen are to really create a culture that does a couple of things. First, it has to be one that understands and expects that people don't know all of this (DEI) and they're going to mess up. That's key.

When one of my kids was in preschool, every morning they repeated their values as a class and one of their values was, "We make mistakes." When that becomes part of who you are, then you are not scared to try new things and to do hard things. You don't necessarily feel bad when you mess up, you just want to figure out what to do differently, and what to do better, and how to learn and how to grow.

That's a culture where it's not walking on eggshells because I don't want to do the wrong thing. But it's understanding that of course you're going to mess up. We all are. But we can get better. That's one of the things that is really important.

The other piece of the culture that I think is just so important is recognizing you can have at the same time, kindness AND accountability. Nobody wants to walk on eggshells, in a place. If you've got a real diversity of people and are trying hard to connect and collaborate and be real, then you're going to make some mistakes, but you're not going to let them slide. You're going to address them in real ways and you're going to move on.

Inclusive leadership is all about making everyone feel welcomed, valued and respected. It's not about excluding some people in our efforts to be more inclusive of others. It's not a zero-sum game.

Hopke: For sure. And it reminds me of something that Renu Sachdeva said in our previous conversation. She mentioned that zero-sum bias, thinking that one person's gain must equal another's disadvantage or loss, is something that can happen consciously or unconsciously. So, for the most part, people don't even realize that's at the root of their feeling excluded or that it could be behind them excluding others.

I believe it really comes down to organizational AND individual mindset shifts on what inclusion truly looks like.

Baran: There are people who genuinely want to do the right thing. They also really want authentic relationships with people who are different from them. It's just that they often don't know how to do it. But what they're going to realize when they do make that shift and start making those connections is that it feels good. And they're going to feel empowered to do it more...hopefully.

Hopke: Hopefully, yes. Because it's those connections that drive change. And it's those connections that fuel the courage that it takes to have the type of conversations that create real change. But that is the antithesis of what we at Talking Talent hear often in our conversations with leaders, "It's safer not to engage so that I don't say or do the wrong thing."

Baran: That's why it's so important to create a space where people can ask questions. Like after I did a talk, an older white gentleman stood up and asked, "Is it even okay, to say the word "black" or "Asian?" l just don't even know what words are going to make people upset and which aren't." We were able to have a real conversation about that. After the talk, his manager came up to me and she said, "This is a testament to this welcoming space, because I can't believe he stood up in front of 500 people and asked that question, which could be really embarrassing for him."

Hopke: That took courage. And I'm sure that there were others who were so glad that he asked because they didn't have the courage to. And that manager is right, the welcoming space made the difference and helped him to take a chance and ask a vulnerable question. We actually suggest that organizations provide group coaching or learning experiences specifically for the majority - to give them an opportunity to connect with others like them in a safe space that allows them to get some of their resentment off their chests. It can be a really powerful experience!

In the day-to-day workplace, how can colleagues encourage the white men they work with to be more vocal and courageous as it relates to DEI, while also helping them to be aware of the potential places where they may be unintentionally "white-splaining" or "man-splaining?"

Baran: We have to take a step back kind of and think about how we are having learning experiences or training for everyone. Because white men don't see it, not all white men, of course, but a lot. I often do talks about how, for example, women get cut off more in meetings or don't get credit for their ideas.

So, I'll tell people about this research that's been done, and it's almost like clockwork that some of the men will turn to the women in the room and say, "Well, that doesn't happen here, right?" And the women go, "Are you kidding me?? Yes, that happens here." But they haven't seen it because it's not happening to them.

So, we have to help them see that and also understand the value of listening. And to make them understand that you're not as good at listening as you think you are. Real listening, not listening when you're formulating what you're going to say in your head, not playing devil's advocate and pushing back for no reason. Not filtering everything someone says, through your own understanding, like, "Well that wouldn't have made me upset. I don't see why you would care about that." They need help to understand what real listening means.

And part of it is an interaction thing, where the other person gets to feel heard. It's not a simple task.

When we got calls after the murder of George Floyd, business were like, "Quick! Get in here! We need listening sessions. We really need to hear from our black and African American colleagues." And we were like, "You're so not ready to even listen. You're going to do real harm actually if you try to jump into this." They needed to take a step back.

The same is true now. You have to first have some sessions on what it means to really listen to people.

Hopke: Right. DEI is not a "please break glass in case of emergency" plan. DEI is meant to be foundational, carefully cultivated, and applied with thoughtfulness and intention. What's your advice for leaders who are willing to take that step back now for reflection so that they can step up for their people in more meaningful ways?

Baran: I often use the analogy of pushups. You're not going to go from never doing a push up to doing 500 pushups a day. It's just not going to happen. You have got to start small and build up those muscles.

And the same thing with D&I. It's going to take building up those muscles. And there is going to be fumbling and stumbling through it a little bit. But that's okay.

Hopke: It's definitely a process. And to your point about really listening to people, that means we must also be ready and willing to tune into what Steven Humerickhouse , who joined us in part 1 of this discussion, calls "the missing voices." He pointed out that this includes white men who may not feel as though they even have a safe space to voice how they are experiencing DEI. They might even be feeling, as Steven said, "You're talking about me without including me in the conversation."

So, what are your thoughts on why white men might feel like they can't authentically take part in the DEI conversation? What could be causing them to feel overlooked, resentful, or unwilling to fully embrace DEI efforts? Can you share what you've seen and heard in your work?

Baran: What I'm seeing is that there are many varied reasons why white men are feeling like outsiders to the DEI conversation.

I think some white men want to play a part in it but feel hesitant and fearful that they won't be welcomed or that they will say the wrong thing. They worry about not understanding the core concepts or issues and wonder if they do participate, they might somehow be seen as inauthentic.

For others, they don't see how it's a conversation that is about them, so they may be more actively resistant. That's why they may push back against some of the DEI efforts and concepts in their organizations. Also, from their perspective, they are even being blamed for the issues. So, they do not want to put themselves in a position where they would be made to feel bad or guilty.

Then there are white men who are anti-DEI because they have bought into some of the divisive political rhetoric that distorts and manipulates DEI issues.

And I believe many white men can struggle with DEI conversations because of the way that they have been socialized. They may find it difficult to really hear other perspectives, to see the subtle ways they have been centered and validated. It's hard for them to conceptualize what it means to have true inclusion and equity for all.

I also think that a lot of people, white men included, are struggling right now. And so white men in particular may feel resentful that people are making assumptions about them and their privilege, without hearing or caring for those struggles.

These are just some of the reasons I have encountered in my work and in my research.

Hopke: And I'd like to add that tapping into empathy can take you far, too. Someone on my team said recently, "Oh, the places you will go when empathy is leading the way." I've seen that to be true in my work of helping leaders to build more inclusive cultures, even when they are still trying to get buy-in across the organization.

For inclusive leaders who are wanting to be empathetic in addressing this issue of white men feeling excluded from DEI, how can they help others on their teams to do the same? Especially when those people might be feeling frustrated that this is even an issue - particularly when the underrepresented talent in the organization are those who have been historically and systematically excluded at work and in society at large?

Baran: That's a great question. I mean the ironic thing is others probably do have some empathy. They probably can understand it, because they've been through it.

Because they have been marginalized and I think that's one of the key foundations of empathy. They probably do get it.

But the much harder task is getting those white men to realize that this has been happening for so long to these people who have been marginalized. And to really understand that and to not think that everything's been so fair and equal and now all of a sudden white men are getting sidelined.

That feels like a much harder task. If you said, "Michael, you have to speak to this group of marginalized people and your goal is to get them to have empathy for these white men." I might just say, "You know how you've been feeling this for so long? You don't want other people to feel that. If we really want to work together right, we've got to make everyone feel valued and so we've got to figure out a way to come together and do that."

Hopke: And what would you say are the hallmarks of organizations that do "work together right"?

Baran: One piece of it is doing an audit or something, making sure that all your policies and procedures and practices are creating equity and inclusion and not the opposite. That's important because then you've got data.

Also there needs to be a learning journey of sorts to get people where they need to be and getting everyone on the same page with various trainings. For people managers and for all staff - getting people on board with the same framework and language and understanding is so key so you feel like you're in this together. It's not one thing that's being done for people. But we're all in together to make our organization as strong as it can be.

It's a good thing for people to get that inclusion and equity is great for all people. And it's also good for business. If it was bad for business, it would be a hard sell. Luckily, it's also good for business!

Hopke: What are you really proud of with the work you're doing right now?

Baran: I am really proud of how we address the issues. More inclusion and equity for everyone, not at the expense of some people, but really everyone. And I'm proud to be facilitating connections. Those real connections. Human connections feel good and help us advance.

Hopke: That's always the best. And that's my hope for the clients that we get to work with in this space. That we can help them rethink DEI and their part to play in it in ways similar to how you are.

It's important to remember that DEI is not about finger-pointing or making anyone feel guilty, regardless of what some commentators or politicians might suggest. But it's about creating a more inclusive environment for everyone, and that can only be done when we create genuine experiences and spaces where everyone is heard, understood, and aligned around the purpose behind creating a more equitable world of work.

We have to clear the eggshells, take out the taboo around it, and ensure that people aren't coming to the table with fear or resentment but rather open hearts and minds that will ensure NO ONE (not even white men) is overlooked or excluded.

Thinking Of God As A White Man Contributes To Bias Says New Study

By Kim Elsesser

By Kim Elsesser ,

Senior Contributor.

Many depictions of God such as this one from The Creation of Adam, on the ceiling of the Sistine ... More Chapel portray God as a white man. (Photo by Art Images via Getty Images)

It's no secret that white men dominate leadership positions in the U.S., but a new set of studies suggest that conceptualizing God as a white man may contribute to the bias that favors white men in leadership positions. Researchers found that the more study participants thought of God as white and male, the more likely they were to think that white men made better leaders.

According to the set of studies published in the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology , how we picture God may impact how we think about race and gender. Not surprisingly, Christians in the United States are more likely to think of God as male than female. When it comes to race, the researchers found that white Christians tended to think of God as an old white man, and black Christians tended to conceptualize God as an old black man. The researchers also searched for "God" in Google Images. Of the images that were relevant to religion and depicted a humanized God, 87.5% depicted a white person, 74% depicted a man and 72% depicted a white man.

Not only do images of God as a white man dominate many psyches and web searches, but conceptualizing God in this way also has an impact on who we think will be a good leader. Those who were more likely to think of God as a white man tended also to believe that white men were the best choice for supervisory positions.  This held true for male, female, black and white participants, and held even after controlling for racist and sexist attitudes, religiosity and political attitudes.

Still, it's not clear from this study that thinking of God as a white man actually causes people to think white men are better fit for leadership.  In other words, the study doesn't demonstrate that our mental image of God directly impacts our thinking about who make the best leaders.

Bias On A Fictional Planet

In order to test if our conceptualization of God actually impacts our thoughts on leadership, the researchers started over with a fictional God on the imaginary planet, Zombot.  Planet Zombot, new study participants were told, was inhabited by two kinds of creatures called Hibbles and Glerks. Both Hibbles and Glerks believed that Liakbor the Creator had created Zombot, and both groups prayed to this creator. Study participants were told that Liakbor was a Hibble, and that both Hibbles and Glerks recognized that Liakbor was a Hibble. When these study participants asked which group should have the majority of leadership positions on Zombot, most said Hibbles should.

What happens to these attitudes if the inhabitants believe that a god is of one race, but, in reality, that god is a different race? To test this, other participants were told that in reality Liakbor was a Glerk, but the inhabitants of Zombot didn't know this, and the inhabitants thought Liakbor was a Hibble. Participants in this case thought Glerks were best-suited for leadership. This is an important finding because it shows that the actual race of the god is more important than the general feeling about the race of the god in determining who is best suited for leadership.

Children May Be The Key To Reducing This Bias

These studies were replicated with children, indicating these connections start at a young age.  In the U.S., Christian children, both white and racial minority, thought of God as more white than black and more male than female. This resulted in the children perceiving white people as particularly boss-like. In the case of Zombot, agnostic preschoolers  (who said they had never heard of God) were told that Liakbor created Zombot and everything on it. The preschool children were then asked which group was more likely to rule on Zombot and live in a castle. The children chose the group that looked most like Liakbor, indicating that those who look like a creator are more suited for leadership.

Lead author of the study and Stanford psychology professor, Steven Roberts thinks kids may hold the key to addressing this problem, but it won't be easy.  "The remedy seems to be to prevent children from even acquiring the God equals white male association. That is going to be a super difficult task because that image is pervasive and passionately defended. It really is a difficult problem and even some of the well-intentioned ministers I work with are scratching their heads as to how to fix it," he says.

Women face additional barriers to leadership inside the church that may also translate to perceptions of women's fitness for leadership outside the church. Many religious groups allow only men to be clergy , often citing The Bible as justification. For example, "A woman should learn in quietness and full submission. I do not permit a woman to teach or to assume authority over a man; she must be quiet," from The New Testament, 1 Timothy 2:11 is often cited as a reason why women shouldn't hold leadership positions in church.  Although there are many different interpretations of this passage, it's not a stretch to think that those who believe this is true for the church, also are more likely believe it's true outside the church.

There is no simple solution to these issues. Beliefs about God and religion are deeply ingrained and attempts to change them can backfire. When the researchers showed a painting that depicted God as a black woman, respondents expressed disbelief and negativity. One African American woman who viewed the painting remarked, "The artist is challenging the notion that #1 God is a man, #2 God is White. If I were at an art gallery and saw this painting, I would walk by shaking my head as it is just one more politically correct recreation of who God is. Disgusting!"

A large number of scientific, technical and academic professions - including computer programming, mathematics, physics, chemistry, engineering, etc. - are inordinately dominated at all levels (undergraduate, graduate school, early career, senior positions) by white males, far in excess of what one would expect if there were a level playing field.

The gender and racial disparities in these (and other) fields cannot be explained away by the "inherent differences" hypothesis . However, there are real, ubiquitous, and pervasive problems that disproportionately affect women, people of color, and all underrepresented minorities. This includes not only harassment, but many inappropriate behaviors that add up to send the toxic message of, " you don't belong here ."

Thankfully, more and more voices are speaking up to counter that message. Here are six steps that you can take to help.

Step 0: You have to care . I know, it's not fair to say there are six steps and then to pull out a "step 0" to start, but this is to illustrate what I feel is an extremely important point: not everyone begins at the same starting line. When people with the same superficial attributes as you - particularly on the metrics of race, gender, gender identity, sexual orientation, language or religion - are not well-represented in your field, it's often assumed that you don't belong.

People of color, women, LGBTQ+ individuals, members of the disability community, and many others are often given insufficient credit for their contributions to group projects, even when they're the principal investigator. They encounter a default assumption that they're junior, that they're less competent or knowledgeable, and that the white, male members of their collaboration are the only possible real contributors. People who have to fight underrepresentation on multiple fronts simultaneously (e.g., black lesbians with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) receive the "you don't belong here" message more strongly than anyone.

In 2011, the Boston's Museum of Science held the first national exhibition, RACE, to tell the ... [+] stories of race from the biological, cultural, and historical points of view. Combining these perspectives offers an unprecedented look at race and racism in the United States. The exhibit was developed by the American Anthropological Association in collaboration with the Science Museum of Minnesota. (David L Ryan/The Boston Globe via Getty Images)

It should go without saying that these attitudes are harmful to everyone, as anytime a large number of qualified, intelligent researchers are pushed out of a field, it's not just those individuals but the entire scientific endeavor that suffers. In order to even get your foot in the door as an underrepresented minority (URM), you have to:

People who are smart, talented, qualified, competent, interested and capable come in all shapes, sizes and colors. The playing field is not level. If you're interested in being an ally, you'll take steps to actively counteract the unfair inequities bred into the system. (And if you've read this far and determined you're not interested in being an ally, you can stop here. This article is not for you.)

One of uncountably many incidents that actually occur in the sciences on a near-daily basis that ... [+] illustrate how casually discriminatory attitudes can undermine and marginalize members of underrepresented groups.

Step 1: Listen to (women/people of color/URMs) when they discuss the problems they face . This is the first real step towards being an ally, and all it requires you do to is pay attention to the many voices out there - especially the voices of people whose experiences are vastly different from your own - and pay attention to them.

You'll find lots of challenges that they talk about, and a myriad of ways that people are given the message that they are inadequate. This is a problem that practically everyone faces, but the degree of severity of this problem varies drastically among people of different races, genders, sexual orientations, religions, and ages. Many things that we think of as minor offenses if they only happen once or twice become unbearable, like death-by-a-thousand-papercuts, when they happen continually.

Over a century ago, women experienced vastly different treatment than men in academic circles and ... [+] institutions. Here in 2019, the playing field is still far from level, although the reasons are far more insidious than overt these days.

Step 2: Resist the urge to compare your own experiences with theirs . Yes, you have experienced unfairness in your life. You may have even - in many regards - experienced unfairness at a level where the injustices you've been forced to endure are greater than many of the underrepresented minorities you're expected to be an ally for. Your experiences, struggles, and injustices are your own, for sure, and no one should make you feel like your struggles aren't real.

But the very real adversities you've faced in your own life don't in any way invalidate the obstacles that people whose experience you don't share encounter. When someone shares their story about an injustice they've faced, you can either take the initiative to help, reach out to be supportive (and to ask how if you don't know), or simply let them know you have their back. Under no circumstances should you tell them that their experiences are wrong, untrue, invalid, or that they need to toughen up and get over it. And, as a bonus, try to never start a sentence with the words, "well, actually..."

Step 3: Recognize that "treating everyone the same" can magnify, not erase, pre-existing inequalities . When I first got to college as an undergrad, I had a problem: my de facto instinct was to call all of my instructors "Mr. or Ms. Name," rather than Dr. or Professor. I didn't intend any disrespect, but while the white male professors chuckled, the professors who were women or people of color were clearly grinning-and-bearing-it.

Why? Because even coming from an 18 year old student, that message of "you don't belong here" still rang in their ears in a way it didn't for the professors who were white men. Many prestigious colleges and universities will still default to sending invitations to "Dr. Man and Ms. Woman" to married couples who are both professors; many URM professors have to endure being casually lectured about their own areas of expertise.

There are small behavioral changes we can all make, as allies, to help mitigate the ways that the playing field isn't inherently level. By publicly treating URMs with the respect they're due, we can help instill the expectation that you cannot tell someone's competence or expertise by a cursory look at their appearances. By the same token, if we fail to recognize how URMs in our field experience their profession differently from our own experiences, we cannot begin to support them.

Harassment and bullying of graduate students in academia is a rampant problem, and one that is ... [+] regarded as likely partially (if not wholly) responsible for the gender disparity at the highest professional levels in the sciences. This is a problem that will require action from the top to eradicate. If you're a prospective graduate student, talk to the other students to get a feel for how bad racism, sexism, and other discrimination/bigotry problems are for the students in your prospective department.

Step 4: When you learn about one way that URMs experience inequality, look at your own actions . Are you actively working to counteract that inequality? How are you doing that? Is it effective in creating a welcoming environment for the URMs you're trying to support? Is there a way you can do that in a better fashion?

When I first earned my Ph.D., it was a novel experience that some people called me "Dr. Siegel," but I quickly found that it created an extra "distance" between myself and my students. So I told them to call me "Ethan" to put them at ease, and that was how I started living: everyone could call me by my first name and I could call everyone by their first name. Now that I had attained the highest educational degree possible in my own field, I wasn't being disrespectful to anyone.

U.S. Department of Education Program Legal Group (Title IX), from the United States Department of ... [+] Agriculture. Although bullying and harassing behavior based on gender is explicitly forbidden, there are currently no punitive measures that are universally taken to enforce this legislation, and the unacceptable behavior is still widespread.

That was my thought, at least: a totally reasonable line of thought. Of course, my experience of getting the "you don't belong here message" was very different than that of URMs, and - in retrospect - one of my lowlights came about three years ago at an astronomy press conference. I was very interested in one of the presentations, given by a woman scientist in my field, and I casually referred to her by her first name, asked my questions, and got some wonderful knowledge out of it.

But this wasn't in private; this was in public. In front of dozens of other professionals in our male-dominated field, I addressed a woman scientist by her first name. In isolation, perhaps that would be no big deal, and maybe even today she doesn't think it was a big deal. But it's such a small behavioral change to just be a little bit thoughtful - to care enough about their experiences to change your own actions slightly - to give URMs in your field the respect that is so often withheld from them, and to recognize that the respect freely given to you may not be so freely given to them.

The three key points in the largest study of harassment in astronomy point to women of color ... [+] experiencing the largest amounts of gender and racial harassment, large levels among women and women of color specifically of feeling unsafe due to gender and race, and women skipping professional events due to feeling unsafe, leading to lost career opportunities.

Step 5: When you witness someone in the "in-group" saying something unacceptable about women/PoC/URMs, speak up . One of the often-invisible obstacles faced by minoritized groups is the fatigue they face from the extra burden of having to endure the hurtful words and actions of bigots, harassers, and well-meaning but under-informed nincompoops. The following lines of question are common:

Yet every time such a question comes up, it places an enormous additional burden on the person - almost always an underrepresented minority in some form - solely on the basis of their minoritization in that field. If you are a non-minority in that field (or anywhere), and especially if you're already part of that conversation, do absolutely intervene. Why's that? The answer is in this last and final step...

Healthy work environments where people of all races, genders, and religions can work together ... [+] productively and without bullying or harassing behavior occurring must become the norm. Anything less should be unacceptable. Here, the Mars SAM Team celebrates the perfect landing of their rover.

Step 6: Don't stop striving to improve your allyship . Being an ally is not about doing the bare minimum. You cannot simply state, "well, I don't think of myself as racist/misogynist/homophobic/bigoted, and therefore I'm part of the solution." Being an ally is all about supporting people who face additional challenges over and above and outside the experience of the ones you face, and that means continuously working to better support their success in your field, even if it means doing something that works against your own personal interest.

So say something when you see the older, male professor behaving in a sexually inappropriate way towards his junior, female students. Speak up about the existence of non-binary people when your coworker sees the options for "gender" under the drop-down menu as "M," "F," and "other" and laughs, even if there are no non-binary people (that you know of) in your workplace. And absolutely resist the urge to make the discussion about you; it isn't. It's about knowing what the right thing to do it, and doing it, in a world where not being an ally is a whole lot easier.

You won't get a gold star, a certificate, or any accolades for doing it. You may even receive derision for your efforts, along with accusations of grandstanding, white-knighting, or virtue signaling. Being an ally is about doing what's right at the individual level, at the department/workplace level, and for the entire field. The best part of it is that you can become one at any point in time, simply by making the decision that others - even those who have superficial features that differ from your own - deserve to be there just as much as you do. The joys and wonders of science are for everyone to enjoy and explore. It's up to us to make that message as inclusive as possible.

It's taking a literal revolution in the streets to push venture capitalists to more openly look at their portfolio of startups and admit that there's a distinct pattern in who gets access to funding and crowned the next big startup. The pattern, as we well know, is a near-homogenous stream of white men .

So much has been done to shine a light on this endemic issue that's been a barrier to anyone who doesn't fit Silicon Valley's mold of young white men who hold degrees from top-tier universities.

Year after year, the severe lack of funding for diverse-led startups has been covered by nearly every major news outlet . It's been talked about at major tech conferences ; published in research showing the ROI of backing diverse founders; the issue has been at the center of advocacy campaigns launched by nonprofits . We've seen it trending in hashtags like #changetheratio and #femalefounders . It's inspired the launch of emerging funds by first-time fund managers, (including my own, the W Fund ) whose primary goal is to invest in diverse founders, because they understand the investment opportunity associated with these underfunded startups.

And the list goes on. But why is all this evidence still not enough to see a real change reflected in startups that get the lion's share of funding?

Investing in diverse-led startups isn't about charity or altruism. Rather, this is about capturing an opportunity to back startups whose leadership understands untapped market needs. It's about creating the future of tech to solve its biggest problems while addressing society's structural issues in building economic power beyond the 1%. And it's about harnessing huge potential to generate high returns. In other words: It's also about money.

Venture capitalists (VCs) and limited partners (LPs) have missed out on trillions of dollars by overlooking scores of founders of startups and emerging funds who are women, Black, Indigenous, and people of color, LGBTQ+, those over the age 50, immigrants, and others.

According to Lo Toney, founder of Plexo Capital, "We have enough reports from the Harvard's and the McKinsey's of the world to show us that diversity at all levels matters. "

Toney is now on his second fund. To his point, plenty of data shows a strong ROI linking diversity in startup founders to generating better financial performances .

Currently, only 2.7% of VC investment goes to women-led startups. And of all VC funding over the past decade, Latinx women-led startups have raised only 0.32% while black women have raised only .0006%. This is all despite the fact that women drive  60% to 70% of consumer behavior in the US, and the data shows that startups led by women achieve a 35% higher return on investment, and, when venture backed, generate 12% higher revenue, according to the Kauffman Foundation . Black women founders and Latinx founders are the fastest growing demographic of entrepreneurs in the US; between 2007 and 2018, the number of Latinx women-owned businesses increased by 172% and the number of Black-women owned businesses rose 164% . According to First Round Capital's portfolio , companies founded by women outperformed companies founded by men by 63%.

In 2020, the new momentum by VCs to publicly discuss racial justice, the industry's systemic biases, and their own role in not doing enough to #changetheratio is a step in the right direction. But words and intention are meaningless unless backed up with action. We need to massively scale funding and support for diverse-led startups. We need to kick those closed doors and networks wide open.

If you're a VC, start those business processes to expand your pipeline ASAP. Assess the structures you've put in place to recruit and meet startups and take them through due diligence. Do these processes rely on criteria or channels that are biasing your systems to favor startups predominantly led by white men with specific backgrounds?

To increase your pipeline, have the most senior leadership (meaning the decision-makers) set up office hours devoted to meeting with founders who aren't in your usual network, or where you haven't had warm intros. This will provide you with more access to startups led by diverse founders. Then, close the deals and #sendthewire .

If you're an LP and want to increase your potential returns, start investing in emerging funds and fund managers who tend to have access to the most diverse pipeline of startups. Ask for a seat at their table.

If you're in tech, a startup founder with an exit, and/or have the ability and accreditation to invest, consider being an angel investor in early-stage startups or becoming an LP in an emerging fund. Help change the system within.

If VCs and LPs are truly invested in forging a more equitable ecosystem with venture returns than they will start putting their money where their mouth is. We've seen too many social media campaigns, and too much evidence about who will drive a healthy financial future, to let this be a passing trend. We've started too many important conversations about the racial inequity in tech and startups to go back.

Historically, it's been in trying economic times like the present when we've seen the next crop of unicorns emerge. I believe (and exhaustive evidence supports the theory) that the next Jeff Bezos will be a diverse founder.
